direction.raw_text: . SUMMER COTTAGE -- DAY A young family together in bed.  It is a bright summer morning.  Father, mother, and a three year old girl are still asleep.  They are naked. direction.raw_text: . AIRPLANE. FIRST CLASS CABIN -- DAY In the mirror of the tiny washroom of the plane, MITCHELL washes some water on his face.  He stares at his reflection in the mirror. CUT TO EXT. THE OTTOS HOUSE. -- DAY MITCHELL approaches the house of HARTLEY and WANDA OTTO.  He gets out of his car and knocks on the door.

direction.raw_text: Mrs. Otto, my name is Mitchell Stephens.  The Walkers told me you might be willing to talk to me. Pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry for coming over unannounced like this, Mrs. Otto, but the Walkers said you would understand.  I know it's an awful time, but it's important that we talk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who are you?
direction.name: direction

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please.

direction.raw_text: pauses, stares at MITCHELL, then lets him in.

direction.raw_text: . THE OTTOS HOUSE. -- DAY MITCHELL walks into the OTTO residence.  It is a large two- storey space divided into several smaller chambers with sheets of brightly colored cloth - tie-dyes and Indian madras - that hang from wires. On a low brick platform in the centre of the main chamber is a large wood-burning stove.  A few feet from the stove, sitting on an overstuffed cushion, is HARTLEY OTTO.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: is listening to music on his headphones.  He is very stoned.  WANDA moves over, and pulls the headphones off her husband's head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We have a guest.  What did you say your name was?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mitchell Stephens.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: hands them a card.  HARTLEY reads it with deliberation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Walkers sent him by.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: rises up.  He stares at MITCHELL.  A tense pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You want a cup of tea or something?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A cup of tea would be nice. (beat) Would it be alright if I sit down for a few minutes, Mrs. Otto?  I want to talk to you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: stares at MITCHELL.  No response.  MITCHELL waits a beat, then seats himself rather uncomfortably on a large pillow.  He is unsure whether to cross his legs, or fold them under his chin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Walkers spoke very highly of you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You've been retained?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Their child died, and they got a lawyer. Pause.  MITCHELL assesses WANDA'S energy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It should be said that my task is to represent the Walkers only in their anger.  Not their grief.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who did they get for that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You are angry, aren't you, Mrs. Otto?  That's why I'm here.  To give your anger a voice.  To be your weapon against whoever caused that bus to go off the road.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dolores?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's my belief that Dolores was doing exactly what she'd been doing for years.  Besides, the school board's insurance on Dolores is minimal.  A few million at the very most.  The really deep pockets are to be found in the town, or in the company that made the bus.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You think someone else caused the accident?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mrs.  Otto,  there is no such thing as an accident.  The word doesn't mean anything to me.  As far as I'm concerned, somebody somewhere made a decision to cut a corner.  Some corrupt agency or corporation accounted the cost variance between a ten-cent bolt and a million dollar out-of-court settlement.  They decided to sacrifice a few lives for the difference.  That's what's done, Mrs. Otto.  I've seen it happen so many times before.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: returns with the tea.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But Dolores said she saw a dog and tried to...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How long has Dolores been driving that bus, Mr. Otto?  How many times has she steered clear of danger? What went wrong that morning?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: takes the cup of tea.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Someone calculated ahead of time what it would cost to sacrifice safety.  It's the darkest, most cynical thing to imagine, but it's absolutely true.  And now, it's up to me to make them build that bus with an extra bolt, or add an extra yard of guard rail.  It's the only way we can ensure moral responsibility in this society.  By what I do. Pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So you're just the thing we need.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Excuse me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Isn't that what you want us to believe?  That we're completely defenseless?  That you know what's best?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Listen to me, Mrs Otto.  Listen very carefully.  I do know what's best. As we're sitting here the town or the school board or the manufacturer of that bus are lining up a battery of their own lawyers to negotiate with people as grief-stricken as yourselves.  And this makes me very, very mad.  It's why I came all the way up here.  If everyone had done their job with integrity your son would be alive this morning and safely in school.  I promise you that I will pursue and reveal who it was that did not do their job.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who is responsible for this tragedy. Then, in your name and the Walkers' name and the name of whoever decides to join us, I shall sue.  I shall sue for negligence until they bleed. Pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I want that person to go to jail. For the rest of his life.  I want him to die there.  I don't want his money.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: nods sympathetically.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's unlikely that anyone will go to prison, Mrs. Otto.  But he or his company will pay in other ways.  And we must make them pay.  Not for the money or to compensate you for the loss of your son.  That can't be done.  But to protect other innocent children.  You see, I'm not just here to speak for your anger, but for the future as well. (beat) What we're talking about is an ongoing relationship to time. Pause.  HARTLEY looks at MITCHELL'S teacup.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I didn't ask if you wanted milk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.  A little sugar though.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We've only got honey.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll...take it straight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: maintains his eye contact with WANDA.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you expensive?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If you agree to have me represent you in this suit, I will require no payment until after the case is won, when I will require one third of the awarded amount.  If there is no award made, then my services will cost you nothing.  It's a standard agreement.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you have this agreement with you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's in my car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: gets up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll just be a minute.  Anyhow, you should discuss this all without me before you make any decision.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: moves to the door.

direction.raw_text: . THE OTTOS HOUSE. -- DAY MITCHELL leaves the house and moves to his car.  He gets inside and closes the door. Once inside, MITCHELL opens his briefcase and takes out an agreement for the OTTOS.  Something inside the briefcase catches his attention.

direction.raw_text: ...I've sent her to the best hospitals, she's seen all the best doctors.  It doesn't matter.  Two weeks later she's on the street. New York, Vancouver, Pittsburgh, Toronto, L.A.  The next time I hear from her, it's a phone call scamming for money.  Money for school, or money for a new kind of therapist, or money for a plane ticket home. 'Oh Daddy, just let me come home...Please, Daddy, I have to see you...'  But she never comes home. I'm always at the airport, but she's never there.  Ten years of this, ten years of these lies, of imagining what happens if I don't send the money, of  kicking down doors and dragging her out of rat-infested apartments, of explaining why that couldn't be my daughter in a porn flick someone saw...well, enough rage and helplessness, and your love turns to something else.

direction.raw_text: .  WINTER ROAD -- MORNING The bus comes to a stop where a couple of children in bright snow suits are waiting by the side of the road.  DOLORES opens the door and the kids climb in.

direction.raw_text: (voice over) They had walked to their places on the main road from the smaller lanes
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: and private roadways that run off it.  Bright little clusters of three and four children - like berries waiting to be plucked.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DOLORES'S HOUSE -- DAY DOLORES is continuing her conversation with MITCHELL.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's the way I thought of them sometimes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Berries.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.  Like I was putting them into my big basket.  Clearing the hillside of its children. Pause.  MITCHELL stares at DOLORES, disturbed by this image.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: looks back at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Abbott and I used to do a lot of that in the spring.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Berry-picking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.  The old-fashioned way.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And what's that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With our hands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: nods, stealing a glance ABBOTT, who stares at him intensely.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BIDE-A-WILE MOTEL -- MORNING The bus pulls up across the road from the Bide-A-Wile Motel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: watches as RISA walks her little boy, SEAN, across the road to the bus.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anyhow, my next stop was across from the Bide-A-Wile, which is owned and operated by Risa and Wendell Walker. Risa walked her little boy, Sean, across the road, which was customary.  Sean had some kind of learning disability.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He was behind all the other kids his age in school and was too fragile and nervous to play sports.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DOLORES'S HOUSE -- DAY DOLORES continues to talk to MITCHELL, who takes notes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A strange little fellow, but you couldn't help liking him.  He was close to ten but seemed more like a frightened five or six.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Were his parents...attentive to him?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you mean?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You mentioned that he had a learning disability.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's right.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did his parents attend to that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you mean?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did they give him special care?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Walkers loved Sean.  He was their only child...the object of all their attention.  I mean, Wendell's a withdrawn sort of man.  That's his nature.  But Risa, she's still got dreams.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BIDE-A-WILE MOTEL -- MORNING DOLORES opens the door for SEAN.  RISA is wearing a down parka over her nightgown and bathrobe and is wearing slippers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Morning, Dolores.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hi, Risa.  Aren't your feet freezing?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: looks down at her slippers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I guess they are.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: gets to the landing of the bus, then turns around and looks at his mother.  He extends his hands like a baby wanting to be hugged.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I want to stay with you. Pause.  RISA stares at her son with great intensity and feeling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Go on now, Sean.  Go on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: turns away and looks into the bus full of children.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: C'mon, Sean.  Sit next to me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: is sitting beside NICOLE.  NICOLE whispers something to him, and he makes his way for SEAN.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: goes to the back of the bus and sits beside his sister, JESSICA.  SEAN moves tentatively towards NICOLE.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ON Back on DOLORES and RISA.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is he okay?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Temperature?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.  He's not sick or anything. It's just one of those mornings, I guess.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DOLORES'S HOUSE -- DAY DOLORES continues her conversation with MITCHELL STEPHENS.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But I never had 'those mornings' myself.  Not so long as I had the schoolbus to drive.  Not so long as I had my kids.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: is lost in this memory, realizing she will never drive the children again.  A tear runs down her cheek.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: sensing his wife's mood, activates his electric wheelchair and maneuvers himself towards DOLORES.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: watches as DOLORES grasps ABBOTT'S hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . SCHOOL BUS -- MORNING NICOLE is seated in the bus next to SEAN.  She is staring at the large speedometer on the front panel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ON The speedometer reads 51 miles an hour.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . SCHOOL BUS -- MORNING JESSICA and MASON, BILLY'S children, wave at their father from the back of the bus. CUT TO EXT. BILLY'S PICK-UP -- MORNING BILLY waving back at his children.  His expression suddenly changes as he sees... CUT TO EXT. ROAD. -- MORNING From BILLY'S point of view, the schoolbus smashes through the guardrail and the snowbank.  It plummets down the embankment to the frozen-over pond. Still upright, the bus slides across the ice to the far side.  The ice lets go and the rear half of the yellow bus is swallowed at once by the freezing water.  The sound of the ice breaking is terrifying.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It emerged from the blowing snow on the right side of the road.  It might have been a dog or a small deer or maybe even a lost child.  It might have been an optical illusion or a mirage.  Whatever it was, for the rest of my life I will remember that red-brown blur... An eerie silence as the camera stares at the scene of the accident.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . SUMMER COTTAGE -- MORNING The camera is high above the bed, looking down on a sleeping family. This is the same image as from the beginning of the film.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: a MOTHER, and a THREE YEAR OLD GIRL, naked in bed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Every time I get on one of these flights to rescue Zoe, I remember the summer we almost lost her.  She was three years old.  It happened in the morning, at this cottage we used to rent.  We were all sleeping together in bed.  It was a wonderful time in our lives.  We still thought we had a future together, the three of us.  Did you ever visit the cottage?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . AIRPLANE. FIRST CLASS CABIN -- NIGHT MITCHELL is telling the story to ALISON.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...don't think so.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I woke to the sound of Zoe's breathing.  It was laboured.  I looked over and noticed she was sweating and all swollen.  I grabbed her, rushed to the kitchen, and splashed water on her face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What happened?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I didn't know.  I was in a panic.  I guessed she'd been bitten by an insect, but there was no doctor. The nearest hospital was forty miles away, and Zoe was continuing to swell.  Klara took her in her arms and tried to breast-feed her, while I dialed the hospital.  I finally got a doctor on the line.  He sounded young, but cool.  He was confident, but there was a nervousness.  He have been an intern.  This was the first time he ever had to deal with anything like this.  He wanted to seem like he knew what he was doing, but he was just as scared as I was.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: stares at MITCHELL, taken by his need to chronicle and detail this irrelevant stranger.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . SUMMER COTTAGE -- MORNING FATHER (YOUNG MITCHELL) is on the phone.  The camera is behind his head. In front of him, MOTHER (KLARA) is breast-feeding the THREE YEAR OLD GIRL (ZOE).
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He surmised that there was a nest of baby black widow spiders in the mattress.  He told me they had to be babies, or else with Zoe's body weight she'd be dead.  He told me I had to rush her to the hospital.  He was alone.  There was no ambulance available.  'Now you listen', he said, 'There's a good chance you can get her to me before her throat closes, but the important thing is to keep her calm.'  He asked if there was one of us she was more relaxed with than the other.  I said, 'Yes, with me.'
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . AIRPLANE. FIRST CLASS CABIN -- NIGHT MITCHELL continues telling the story to ALISON.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Which was true enough, especially at that moment.  Klara was wild-eyed with fear, and her fear was contagious.  I was a better actor than she was, that's all.  Zoe loved us equally then.  Just like she hates us both equally now. (beat) The doctor told me that I should hold her in my lap, and let Klara drive to the hospital.  He asked me to bring a small, sharp knife.  It had to be clean.  There was no time to sterilize properly.  He explained how to perform an emergency tracheotomy.  How to cut into my daughter's throat and windpipe without causing her to bleed to death.  He told me there'd be a lot of blood.  I said I didn't think I could do it.  'If her throat closes up and stops her breathing, you'll have to, Mr. Stephens.  You'll have a minute and a half, two minutes maybe, and she'll probably be unconscious when you do it.  But if you can keep her calm and relaxed, if you don't let her little heart beat too fast and spread the poison around, then you might just make it over here first.  You get going now', and he hung up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CAR -- MORNING A little girl staring innocently into the lens as a male voice sings a lullaby to her. It is now recognized as MITCHELL'S voice, singing to his daughter as she is driven to the hospital.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It was an unforgettable drive.  I was divided into two people.  One part of me was Daddy, singing a lullaby to his little girl.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The other part was a surgeon, ready to cut into her throat.  I waited for the second that Zoe's breath stopped to make that incision.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . AIRPLANE. FIRST CLASS CABIN -- NIGHT ALISON stares at MITCHELL as he finishes his story.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What happened?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nothing.  We made it to the hospital.  I didn't have to go as far as I was prepared to.  But I was prepared to go all the way.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . ACCIDENT SITE -- DAY An open sky.  BILLY ANSEL'S face appears in the frame, looking down at the camera.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ON The camera is staring down at BILLY as he identifies the bodies of his two children. The camera is at a great height. As BILLY walks away, the camera floats down, slowly moving on his face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . WOODS -- DAY BILLY's P.O.V. of his wife, LYDIA, tugging a sled through the snow.  JESSICA and MASON are on either side of her. The three figures are seen from behind, trudging their way through the winter landscape. This image has a ghostly quality to it.  It is filmed in slow motion. Suddenly, a snowball enters the frame and hits LYDIA on the back of the head.  She turns around, laughing into the camera. CUT TO INT. BIDE-A-WILE MOTEL -- EVENING EXTREME-CLOSE-UP BILLY in his chair in Room 11 of the Bide-A-Wile.  He is alone, smoking a cigarette.  A slight faraway smile on his lips. After a moment, the door opens.  It is RISA. They stare at each other.  Silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I knew you'd be here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: sits on the bed.  Pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you going to the funeral? Pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I stopped by the station a while ago.  I stared at the bus.  I could almost hear the kids inside.  There was a lawyer there.  He told me he'd gotten you signed up.  Is that true?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Something made this happen, Billy. Mr. Stephens is going to find out what it was.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What are you talking about?  It was an accident.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Stephens says that someone didn't put a right bolt in the bus...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Risa, I serviced that bus.  At the garage.  There's nothing wrong with it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...or that the guardrail wasn't strong enough.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You believe that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have to.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Because I have to.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well I don't.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: gets up to leave.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is it true that you gave Nicole one of Lydia's dresses?  That she was wearing it when the bus crashed?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why did you do that, Billy?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You think that caused the accident, Risa?  That it brought bad luck? Christ, it sounds to me you're looking for a witch doctor, not a lawyer.  Or maybe they're the same thing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: is crying.  BILLY opens the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know what I'm going to miss? More than making love?  It's the nights you couldn't get away from Wendell.  It's the nights I'd sit in that chair for an hour.  Smoking cigarettes and remembering my life before...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: stares at RISA painfully, then leaves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . GAS STATION -- NIGHT MITCHELL is videotaping the bus with a portable camcorder. The bus is badly damaged, though essentially intact.  Most of the windows in the rear have gone.  There is a ghostly quality to this image, as though the video light is searching through the remains of an ancient shipwreck.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: turns off the camcorder and stands in the silent night, absorbing the disturbing energy of the bus.  He hears a truck approaching the garage from the distance.  It's
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .  MITCHELL retreats to his parked car as BILLY stops his truck in front of the bus and steps out of the truck.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: leaves his headlights on, and they cast dark shadows over the inside passenger seats.  BILLY stares at the bus a long time.  MITCHELL approaches him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm here about your children, Mr. Ansel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: takes a moment, then turns around to face MITCHELL. The two men stare at each other.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My name is...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mister, I don't want to know your name.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I understand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No you don't.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can help you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not unless you can raise the dead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: hands BILLY a card.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Here.  You may change your mind.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: looks at the card.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Mitchell Stephens, Esquire, would you be likely to sue me if I was to beat you right now?  Beat you so bad that you pissed blood and couldn't walk for a month.  Because that's what I'm about to do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, Mr. Ansel.  I wouldn't sue you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Leave us alone, Stephens.  Leave the people of this town alone.  You can't help.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You can help each other.  Several people have agreed to let me represent them in a negligence suit. Your case as an individual will be stronger if I'm allowed to represent you together as a group.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Case?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Walkers have agreed.  The Ottos. Nicole Burnell's parents.  It's important to initiate proceedings right away.  Things get covered up. People lie.  That's why we have to begin our investigation quickly. Before the evidence disappears. That's why I'm out here tonight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know Risa and Wendell Walker. They wouldn't hire a goddamned lawyer.  And the Ottos wouldn't deal with you.  We're not country bumpkins you can put a big city hustle on.  You're trying to use us.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're angry, Mr. Ansel.  You owe it to yourself to feel that way.  All I'm saying is let me direct your rage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: stares at MITCHELL with a cold intensity.  The cell phone in MITCHELL'S car begins to ring.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's my daughter.  Or it may be the police to tell me that they've found her dead.  She's a drug addict.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why are you telling me this?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm telling you this because... we've all lost our children, Mr. Ansel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They're dead to us.  They kill each other in the streets.  They wander comatose in shopping malls.  They're paralyzed in front of televisions. Something terrible has happened that's taken our children away. It's too late.  They're gone. The phone continues to ring, as BILLY stares at MITCHELL.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: turns to look at the ringing phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DOLORES'S HOUSE -- DAY MITCHELL is getting ready to leave.  DOLORES is still grasping onto ABBOTT'S hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have a question for you, Mr. Stephens.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's that, Dolores?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I told you that I was doing fifty miles an hour when the accident happened.  That's how I remembered it.  But the truth is, I might have been doing sixty.  Or sixty five. And if that's true, that I was over the limit when the bus went over, what would happen then?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That would complicate things.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Because I'd be to blame, right?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Billy Ansel will insist that you were driving fifty-one miles an hour.  Just like you've done every morning for the past fifteen years.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He knows that?  Billy?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.  He does.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Billy said that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You've talked to Billy?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I did.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And Billy told you that he'll tell that to...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mrs.  Driscoll, if Billy Ansel does not volunteer to say so in court, I will subpoena him and oblige him to testify to that effect. Pause.  MITCHELL plans his next step.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But in order to do that, you must let me bring a suit in your name charging negligent infliction of emotional harm.  That's what I'm now asking you to consider. Pause.  DOLORES is lost.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's clear to me and other people that you have suffered significantly from this event.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What other people?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Excuse me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who's been talking to you about what I'm feeling?  Who should care about what I'm feeling?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: stares at DOLORES.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dolores, people have to know that you've suffered too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And they won't understand until you let me clear your name - your good name - once and for all.  Will you let me do that?  Will you let me do my duty? Suddenly, ABBOTT says something.  He twists his face around his mouth, purses his lips on the left side and emits a string of broken syllables and sounds.  After this outburst,
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: looks at MITCHELL, a comforted smile on her face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You heard what Abbott said?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anything you didn't understand?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There might have been a word or two that slipped by.  Maybe you could clarify it for me, just to be absolutely sure.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Abbott said that the true jury of a person's peers is the people of her town.  Only they, the people who have known her all her life, and not twelve strangers, can decide her guilt or innocence.  And if I have committed a crime, then it's a crime against them, so they are the ones who must decide my punishment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: stares at ABBOTT, who stares back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's what he said, is it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.  Abbot understands these things.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DOLORES'S HOUSE -- DAY MITCHELL leaves the DRISCOLL house, watched by DOLORES.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: is in bed.  A doctor, DR. ROBESON, is touching her forehead.  NICOLE'S family (SAM, her mother
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: and her little sister JENNY)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The mind is kind. The camera fixes on NICOLE'S expression as she stares ahead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They say I'm lucky because I can't remember the accident.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't even try to remember.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You just think about getting well, Nicole, that's all. The camera is always fixed on NICOLE'S face when her voice over is heard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know I'm as well as I ever can be again.  So shut up, Mom.  To stay like this, to live like a slug, I'm going to have to work like someone trying to get into the Olympics.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just wait till you see what we've got waiting for you at home.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . HOSPITAL -- DAY NICOLE, in a wheelchair, is being led down a hallway with her family.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's an incredible relief to be leaving the hospital.  I'm so sick of looking at my doctor, listening to Frankenstein ask me stupid questions about what I was feeling...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . HOSPITAL. LOBBY. -- DAY NICOLE is being wheeled to the front door of the hospital.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He thought it was cute when I called him Frankenstein.  It wasn't.  I feel like his monster.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Isn't it a lovely day?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What happened to summer?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Summer's over.  It's fall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And winter?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, winter's far behind us now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How was it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We had a terrible winter last year, didn't we, Sam?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good thing I was in Florida.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: doesn't know quite what to make of NICOLE'S joke.  SAM flashes NICOLE a smile.  She doesn't return it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BURNELL HOME -- DAY NICOLE arrives at home.  The car pulls up in front of the modest house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: opens the door and puts the wheelchair up next to it. He points out the ramp he has built for NICOLE. The ramp is painted green.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How do you like it, Nicole?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The ramp?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pretty slick, eh?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Very slick.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you like the colour?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's okay.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And I had to widen a few doors. You'll see.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BURNELL HOME -- DAY Inside the house.  The interior of the house is dark and somewhat tawdry.  The BURNELL'S are almost poor. But SAM then leads NICOLE into the special room he has built for her.  It seems like another world.  Every detail has been lovingly attended to.  No expense has been spared to make this room as attractive and inviting as possible. A room that a guilty, abusive father might dream up for his crippled daughter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you think? Pause.  NICOLE wheels around, trying to control her emotions as she inspects the room.  A phone rings in the background.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: goes to answer it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: fixes her gaze at the back of the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The door needs a lock.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sure.  I'll fix it right away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: goes to get his tools.  JENNY stares at NICOLE.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can I come and visit you here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You better.  And you can sleep in my new bed with me too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: grabs her sister's hand, and JENNY moves in close to her.  SAM comes back with the tools.  He starts to screw in the hook.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's too high.  I'll never reach it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh.  I better get some spackle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: leaves again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mommy says you need to lock the boys out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What boys?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: stares at JENNY, as MARY comes back into the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So do you like your new room?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's interesting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your Dad spent all his spare time in here.  He wanted to make it absolutely perfect.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I feel like a princess.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: comes back and begins to work on the door.  NICOLE watches him.  She notices a new computer on a desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is this mine?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.  It's a present.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: From you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.  From Mr. Stephens.  That was him on the phone just now.  He was calling to see how you were.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who's Mr. Stephens?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's a lawyer.  He's our lawyer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You and Mom have a lawyer?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, yes.  He's your lawyer too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My lawyer?  Why do I need a lawyer?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe we shouldn't be talking about this just now, with you barely home. Aren't you hungry, honey?  Want me to fix you something?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.  What's this lawyer business?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: turns to JENNY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jenny, why don't you go and play outside?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: looks at NICOLE.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's given me some stuff too.  Toys, and some books...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jenny.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: turns to leave.  When she's outside, MARY continues.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's a very kind man.  And he knew that you'd need a computer for doing schoolwork.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BURNELL HOME. PORCH -- DAY NICOLE wheels her chair to the exterior porch, where she watches her sister climb a tree.  SAM follows her outside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's because of the accident, Nicole.  Most people in this town whose kids were on the bus have got lawyers.  A lot of people...well, people in this town are very angry. Us included.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But you didn't lose me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, honey.  And we will thank the Lord for that every day and night for the rest of our lives.  But you almost died, and you were badly injured, and you won't be...you can't...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can't walk anymore.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .O.V. of JENNY playing on a tree branch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're going to need special care for a long time to come.  It's not going to be easy.  Not for you, not for any of us.  Because we love you so much.  And it's going to cost money.  More than we can imagine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What about insurance?  Doesn't insurance pay for these things?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Partly.  But there's a lot the insurance doesn't cover.  That's one of the reasons we have a lawyer.  To make sure the insurance gets paid and to help us look after the rest.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How will he do that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, Mr. Stephens is representing several families.  The Ottos, the Walkers, us, and I think a couple more.  Mr. Stephens is suing the town for negligence.  He's sure that the accident could have been avoided if they had done their jobs right. He's a very smart man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: stares at her sister who's at the top of the tree.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: turns to look back at NICOLE. There's a tension, as it seems as though JENNY is going to let herself fall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's the first thing I heard about you.  That you were a smart man. That you  were so smart that you were going to sue the town, then make us all feel better...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . GAS STATION -- NIGHT FLASHBACK to the scene outside the gas station between
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: and BILLY. The cell phone in MITCHELL'S car has begun to ring.  The two men stare at each other.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're good at that.  Good at getting people to believe you could do something for them.  Something they could never do for themselves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: breaks the silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's my daughter.  Or it may be the police to tell me that they've found her dead.  She's a drug addict.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why are you telling me this?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm telling you this because we've all lost our children, Mr. Ansel...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . AIRPLANE. FIRST CLASS CABIN -- NIGHT MITCHELL stares at the sleeping figure of ALISON.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They're dead to us.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . GAS STATION -- NIGHT Back to the scene between BILLY and MITCHELL.  The cellular phone is ringing.  MITCHELL breaks the stare with BILLY and moves to his car. The camera follows him, as BILLY moves back to his truck in the background.  MITCHELL gets in his car and picks up the phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, I'll accept the charges.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Daddy?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . PHONE BOOTH -- AFTERNOON MITCHELL Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm calling because I've got some news for you, Daddy.  Some big news.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: News?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't you want to hear?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.  Give me your news, Zoe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You always think you know what I'm going to say, don't you?  You always think you're two steps ahead of me. The lawyer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell me your news, Zoe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay.  I went to sell blood yesterday.  That's how it is.  I'm in this fucking city where my father is a hot shit lawyer, and I'm selling my blood.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's not news, Zoe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.  But this is.  They wouldn't take my blood.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CAR -- DAY Image of ZOE as a little girl in MITCHELL'S lap.  Her face is swollen.  She is being driven to the hospital.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: is singing her a lullaby. MiTCHELL's conversation with ZOE continues over this image.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you know what that means, Daddy? Does it register?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I tested positive.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Welcome to hard times, Daddy. Pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you want me to do, Zoe? I'll do whatever you want.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I need money.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What for?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You can't ask me that!  Not anymore! You asked me what I wanted.  Not what I wanted it for.  I want money.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you have the blood test?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You don't believe me?  You don't fucking believe me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of...course I do.  I just thought...I could get you another test.  In case the one you got...was wrong.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I like it when you don't believe me, Daddy.  It's better you don't believe me but have to act like you do. Pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can hear you breathing, Daddy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.  I can hear you breathing too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: begins to cry over the phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh God, I'm scared.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I love you, Zoe.  I'll be there soon, and I'll take care of you.  No matter what happens.  I'll take care of you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . AIRPLANE. FIRST CLASS CABIN -- NIGHT MITCHELL is still staring at the sleeping figure of ALISON.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: blanket has fallen to the side.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: lifts the blanket, and covers the sleeping figure of the young woman.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BURNELL HOME -- DAY MITCHELL drives up to the BURNELL home.  He gets out of his car and walks to the front door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: has repainted the ramp. It is now red.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BURNELL HOME.  KITCHEN -- DAY MITCHELL meets NICOLE.  SAM and MARY are also seated at the table. The meeting takes place in the kitchen/diningroom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, Nicole, I've been wanting to meet you for a long time now.  Not just because I've heard so many good things about you, but because, as you know, I'm the guy representing you and your mom and dad and some other folks here in town.  We're trying to generate some compensation, however meager, for what you have suffered, and at the same time see that an accident like this never happens again.  You're central to the case I'm trying to build, Nicole.  But you'd probably just as soon let the whole thing lie.  Just get on with your life as quickly and smoothly as possible.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: nods.  Pause, as MITCHELL waits for her to go on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't like thinking about the accident.  I don't even remember it happening.  Besides, it just makes people feel sorry for me, and...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You hate that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What she means, Mitch...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: silences SAM with a gesture of his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: People can't help it, you know. They really can't.  When they see you in this wheelchair, knowing what your life was life eight months ago, people are going to feel sorry for you.  There's no way around it, Nicole.  You and I just met, and already I admire you.  Who wouldn't? You're a brave tough smart kid. That's obvious.  And I didn't know you, know how exciting and promising your life was before the accident. But listen, even I feel sorry for you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You can only feel lucky that you didn't die for so long.  Then you start to feel...unlucky.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That you didn't die?  Like the other children?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.  Like Bear and the Ansel twins and Sean and...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nicole!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's the truth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: regards MARY with calm authority, as though he's telling her the time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is the truth. Pause.  MITCHELL looks back at NICOLE.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It would be strange if you didn't feel that way.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you want me to do for you, Mr. Stephens?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BURNELL HOME.  LIVINGROOM. -- DAY TIME CUT fifteen minutes forward.  The scene shifts to the livingroom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: and NICOLE are alone in the room.  SAM comes back from another room, as MARY appears from the kitchen with a plate of cookies.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That got you talking about depositions and lawyers.  By the time Daddy came back from the washroom and Mom came in with her tea and cookies, you were going on about how tough it would be for me to answer some of the questions those other lawyers would ask .
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They work for the people we're trying to sue.  Their job is to try to minimize damages.  Our job, Nicole, is to try to maximize them. You have to think of it that way. As people doing their jobs.  No good guys or bad guys.  Just our side and their side.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I won't lie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't want you to lie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The truth is that it was an accident, and no one's to blame.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's no such thing as an accident, Nicole.  Not in a situation like this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You seem very sure about that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm absolutely positive.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: turns to face SAM.  She stares at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No matter what I'm asked, I'll tell the truth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: looks back, expressionless.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's fine.  I want you to be absolutely truthful.  And I'll be right there to advise and help you. And there'll be a court stenographer there to make a record of it, and that's what'll go to the judge, before the trial is set.  It'll be the same for everybody.  They'll be deposing the Ottos and the Walkers, the bus driver...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dolores.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.  Dolores...and even your mom and dad.  But I'll make sure you go last.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So you can keep on getting well before you have to go and do this. It's not going to be easy, Nicole. Do you understand that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When do they award damages?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Depends.  This could drag on for quite a while.  But we'll be there at the end, Sam.  Don't you worry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At that moment, I hated my parents - Daddy for what he knew and had done,
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: and even Mom for what she didn't know and hadn't done.  You told me it wasn't going to be easy.  But as I sat there, staring at Daddy, I knew it was going to be the easiest thing in my life.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BIDE-A-WILE MOTEL -- MORNING REPLAY of the scene of SEAN WALKER entering the bus.  He turns around to face his mother.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I want to stay with you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Go on now.  Go on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: hesitantly turns to face the inside of the bus.  He sees NICOLE BURNELL, who pats the seat beside her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: leaves his place beside NICOLE to make way for SEAN.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: C'mon, Sean, sit next to me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: as she watches SEAN move towards NICOLE.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . COMMUNITY CENTRE. -- DAY DOLORES gives her deposition.  A stenographer takes notes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: listens, along with SCHWARTZ, the opposing lawyer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He never took his eyes off his mother, even as he moved to sit beside Nicole.  He looked frightened.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why would he be frightened?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know.  But it was weird in terms of what happened next.  Sean was still watching his mother.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I shut the door with one hand, and released the brake with the other, and waited for a second for Risa to cross in front of the bus.  There was a sixteen wheeler behind me, and I heard his air brakes hiss as the driver chunked into gear.  I looked into the side view mirror, and saw him move into line behind me.  Then suddenly Sean shrieked...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . SCHOOL BUS -- MORNING SEAN leaps to the front of the bus.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mommy!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What happened then?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sean was all over me, scrambling across my lap to the window.  I glimpsed  Risa off to my left, leaping out of the way of a red Saab that seemed to have bolted out of nowhere. The scene is horrifying, as SEAN watches his mother just missing a terrible accident with the speeding vehicle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sean!  Sit down!  Your Mom's okay! Now sit down!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: sits back down beside NICOLE.  DOLORES slides open her window, and speaks to RISA.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You get his number?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: is stunned.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She was shaken, standing there with her arms wrapped around herself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She shook her head, turned away, and walked slowly back to the office.  I drew a couple of breaths and checked Sean, who was seated now but still craning and looking after his mother.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . COMMUNITY CENTRE. -- DAY The deposition continues.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I smiled at him, but he only glared back at me, as if I was to blame.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . SCHOOL BUS -- MORNING AERIAL VIEW of the bus as it makes its way through the mountains.  NICOLE'S voice is heard reading The Pied Piper from the scene with the ANSEL children.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For he led us, he said, to a joyous land, Joining the town and just at hand, Where waters gushed and fruit-trees grew, And flowers put forth a fairer hue, And everything was strange and new...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . SCHOOL BUS -- DAY A montage showing the faces of the various children in the bus.  These images are intercut with DOLORES'S deposition. CUT TO INT. COMMUNITY CENTRE. -- DAY The deposition.  DOLORES is trying to control her emotions.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I remember wrenching the steering wheel to the right and slapping my foot against the brake petal.  I wasn't the driver anymore.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The bus was like this huge wave about to break over us.  Bear Otto, the Lambston kids, the Hamiltons, the Prescotts, the teenaged boys and girls from Bartlett Hill, Sean, Nicole Burnell, Billy Ansel's twins, Jessica and Mason...all the children of my town.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BURNELL HOME -- NIGHT SAM and JENNY are watching television.  Lumberjack log- rolling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: in her wheelchair, is reading a book off to one corner.  MARY comes into the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That was Billy Ansel on the phone. He wants to come over to talk to us.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did he say what about?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Was he drinking?  Could you tell?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jenny, it's time for you to go to bed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mom...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on, Jen.  I let you watch your nature show.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: reluctantly kisses her father goodnight, then NICOLE. As she leaves the room, MARY starts clearing the table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is he coming over now?  Right away?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's what he said.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: is anxious.  He looks over to NICOLE.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What are you up to, Nicole?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nothing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nothing good on your T.V.?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As opposed to this T.V.?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: stares at SAM.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Besides, I'd like to see Billy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: stares at the television.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ON On the television screen, an image of a studio audience applauding.  The image is silent.  The T.V. is on MUTE.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That wasn't true.  I didn't want to be seen by anyone whose kids had been killed by the accident. Especially not Billy Ansel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: turns her attention back to her parents.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Actually, now that I think about it, I'd just as soon stay in my room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: shoves her wheelchair towards her room, as the camera remains on her face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I remembered all the times I had tucked Jessica and Mason into bed. How they loved to have me read to them before they slept.  There was nothing for me to say to Billy, except I'm sorry.  I'm sorry that your children died when my parent's children didn't.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BURNELL HOME -- NIGHT BILLY pulls up to the BURNELL home.  He gets out of his pick up and approaches the house. CUT TO INT. BURNELL HOME -- NIGHT From her room, NICOLE watches as BILLY approaches the house. He leaves her view as a knock is heard at the door.  NICOLE wheels over to the door and presses her ear to the door so that she can hear the conversation. CUT TO INT. BURNELL HOME.  KITCHEN. -- NIGHT SAM Hey, Billy!  What brings you out on a night like this?  C'mon in.  Take a load off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Would you like a cup of tea, Billy? There's a piece of cake left.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.  No, thanks, Mary.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BURNELL HOME.  KITCHEN/LIVINGROOM -- NIGHT SAM leads BILLY into the livingroom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So what brings you out tonight?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, Sam, I might as well tell you the truth.  It's this lawsuit you've gotten yourself all involved with. I want you to drop the damned thing. Pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't see how that concerns you, Billy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It does concern me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I don't know why it should. There's a whole lot of people in town involved with lawsuits.  We're hardly unique here, Billy.  I mean, I can understand how you feel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, it being so depressing and all.  But it's reality.  You can't just turn this off because you happen to think it's a bad idea.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why not?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Because it's what we have to do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well I don't want a damned thing to do with it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay, fine.  So...stay out of it. Pause.  BILLY stares at SAM.  Tension.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've tried to stay out of it.  But it turns out that's not so easy, Sam.  You've gone and got yourself this lawyer.  Mitchell Stephens. You and Risa and Wendell and the Ottos.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So?  I mean, lot's of folks have got lawyers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But yours is the one who's going to subpoena me, Sam.  Force me to testify in court.  He came by the garage this afternoon.  Gave me this piece of paper.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: reaches into his pocket and shows the paper to SAM.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why would he do that?  You didn't have anything to do with the accident.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Because I was driving behind the bus, Mary.  Because I saw it.  I saw it happen...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: is harrowed by this image.  SAM and MARY stare at him, frightened by his intensity.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If that bastard does subpoena me, if he forces me to go over this again, then all those other lawyers will line up behind him and try and do the same thing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That won't happen, Billy.  Mitch Stephens' case is small, compared to some of those other guys.  The way he told me, all he needs is for you to say what you saw that day, driving behind the bus.  I know it's a painful thing to do, but it'll only take a few minutes of your time.  That'll be the end of it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's wrong, Sam.  You know that. We'll be tangled up in this thing for the next five years.  This is never going to go away...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: C'mon, you know that won't...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We've got lawyers suing lawyers because some people were stupid enough to sign on with more than one of the bastards.  We've got people pointing fingers, making side deals, and dickering over percentages. Yesterday, I heard somebody wants to sue the rescue squad.  The rescue squad.  Because they didn't act fast enough.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: listening from her door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If you two dropped the case, then the others would come to their senses
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: and follow.  You're good sensible parents, you and Mary.  People respect you. Pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, Billy.  We can't drop the lawsuit.  You know how much we need the money.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why?  You got money from Dolores' insurance with the school board.  We all did.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's not enough.  For hospital bills.  For Nicole.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll help pay for Nicole, if that's what you're really talking about. I'll even give you the money I got for my kids. (beat) That's what we used to do, remember? Help each other.  This was a community.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: stares at SAM.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I used to like it here.  I used to care about what happened.  Now I think I'll sell my house and move the fuck away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Billy, please.  The children.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The children.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: looks at SAM and MARY, s strange smile on his face. He moves to leave.  He pauses at the door of the kitchen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How is Nicole?  Is she around?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's resting.  In her room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Say hello for me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BURNELL HOME -- NIGHT BILLY walks to his car.  SAM and MARY watch him from the porch/ramp.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're getting on with our lives, Billy.  Maybe it's time you got on with yours.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: turns around, looks at SAM one final time, then moves to his pick up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BURNELL HOME -- NIGHT NICOLE is watching BILLY from her window.  She is crying.

direction.raw_text: .O.V. of BILLY driving away.
